On 03.12.2009, at 21:51, Noah Campbell wrote:

> It's specific to the brows=
er and the underlying os.  Checkout http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2183 for =
more information on signaling the document extension.  After that it's up t=
o the os.
> 

I know.

> If you want the document to render specifically in=
 the browser (like PDF does in Safari, FF, IE) then you need to have an add=
on that understand that's content-type or content-disposition.  Here's an e=
xample of how to do it on MSFT. http://windowsxp.mvps.org/ie/pdf.htm

This =
is the only kind of information I can find, and it's not what I'm looking f=
or. All of my Google searches show up similar things.

What I'm interested =
in is at least a description explaining how to add media type handlers to d=
ifferent kinds of environments (OS and/or browser). 

> 
> Why not reuse an=
 existing media-type?
> 

I fail to see how that would help me, as I'm tryi=
ng to invoke a particular proprietary handler.

Anyway, it seems this is to=
o OT for this list, so I'll stop and maybe report on research results later=
.

Stefan
--
Stefan Tilkov, http://www.innoq.com/blog/st/

<html><head></head><body style="word-wrap: break-word; -webkit-nbsp-mode: space; -webkit-line-break: after-white-space; "><div><div>On 03.12.2009, at 21:51, Noah Campbell wrote:</div><br class="Apple-interchange-newline"><blockquote type="cite">It's specific to the browser and the underlying os.  Checkout <a href="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2183">http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2183</a> for more information on signaling the document extension.  After that it's up to the os.<div>
<br></div></blockquote><div><br></div>I know.</div><div><br><blockquote type="cite"><div>If you want the document to render specifically in the browser (like PDF does in Safari, FF, IE) then you need to have an addon that understand that's content-type or content-disposition.  Here's an example of how to do it on MSFT. <a href="http://windowsxp.mvps.org/ie/pdf.htm">http://windowsxp.mvps.org/ie/pdf.htm</a></div></blockquote><div><br></div>This is the only kind of information I can find, and it's not what I'm looking for. All of my Google searches show up similar things.</div><div><br></div><div>What I'm interested in is at least a description explaining how to add media type handlers to different kinds of environments (OS and/or browser). </div><div><br><blockquote type="cite">
<div><div><div><br></div><div>Why not reuse an existing media-type?</div><div><br></div></div></div></blockquote><div><br></div>I fail to see how that would help me, as I'm trying to invoke a particular proprietary handler.</div><div><br></div><div>Anyway, it seems this is too OT for this list, so I'll stop and maybe report on research results later.</div><div><br></div><div>Stefan</div><div><div>--</div><div>Stefan Tilkov, <a href="http://www.innoq.com/blog/st/">http://www.innoq.com/blog/st/</a></div></div></body></html>
